p: Putative transmission connections were inferred for 38.2% (423/1106) of the sequences sampled ( Fig. 1). The likelihood that an individual clustered with at least one other individual did not differ by ethnicity, residence, or sex in our study cohort. Bisexuals were less likely to cluster than heterosexuals or MSM ( p = 0.043), and individuals identifying as white ( p ≤ 0.01) were more likely to cluster than other races. Age was also significantly associated with clustering: the mean age of clustered individuals (32.8 years) was 3.5 years younger than non-clustered individuals (36.3 years) (p < 0.001) ( Table 3). There was also a difference in clustering among the studies, likely related to differences in how each cohort was constituted, such as by HIV risk and sampling methods.
